data.text_string: “The artist 1s the one who recaptures that child-like fascination with the world.” -Rick Rubin
“Pay attention to the culture without being driven by the culture.” -Rick Rubin
“The beauty of play is that nothing is at stake.” -Rick Rubin
“The only reason to read a review of your work is for entertainment, or insight into the reviewer. Not for an assessment of the work.” -Rick Rubin
“Iry working while slightly distracted. Driving, walking, swimming. Often the best ideas come when engaged in a different activity.”  -Rick Rubin
"Don't look back. Move on to the next one." -Rick Rubin
"Tune out any criticism and make the work for yourself, then share it." -Rick Rubin
“The only reason to read a review of your work is for entertainment, or insight into the reviewer. Not for an assessment of the work.” -Rick Rubin
"Never underestimate the wisdom of ignorance." -Rick Rubin
“For some people  a first thing to learn  is the ability to process criticism skillfully.” -Rick Rubin
“Art isn’t in the tools, material,equipment you use. It’s in the way you see the world.”  -Rick Rubin
“Part of the artistic journey is about connecting with something inward that is universal.”  -Rick Rubin
“The beauty of play is that nothing is at stake.” -Rick Rubin
“Sometimes adversity creates an environment for good things to grow.” -Rick Rubin
“There is no pure ranking system for artistic success. Only you know if it’s successful or not.”  -Rick Rubn
“Meaning is secondary to Intuitive response. Sometimes mindless play can hold more power than meaning.”  -Rick Rubin
“The search for perfection hinders and often slows down the creative process.” -Rick Rubin
“Creativity can just be in relationship with yourself. No one else need be in the equation.”  -Rick Rubin
“Life and the creative process go hand in hand. They are inextricably linked.”  -Rick Rubin
“What we learn though art can benefit all aspects of life.”  -Rick Rubin
“You can find a way to express yourself without any tools or without any instruments-without any anything. Nothing is required.”  -Rick Rubin
“Paying attention is part of self-expression.” -Rick Rubin
“It may not be possible to know who you are without expressing it.”  -Rick Rubin
Exposure to new ideas opens possibilities in us all.” -Rick Rubin
“Ultimately, if you like what you’re making, that’s all that really matters.”  -Rick Rubin
“Anyone can be creative. It’s our birthright.” -Rick Rubin
“Sharing art is a way we connect. Perhaps the best way.”  -Rick Rubin
“Everyone has different taste. There 1s no right or wrong taste.”  -Rick Rubin
“Failure is the information you need to get where you're going.”  -Rick Rubin
“We find our voice through experimentation.” -Rick Rubin
“Competition 1is a low vibration stimulus.” -Rick Rubin
“Don’t allow an expectation to get in the way of the work, even if it’s your  own expectation.”  -Rick Rubin
“The abstract is where the art happens.” -Rick Rubin
“Don’t allow an expectation to get in the way of the work, even if it’s your  own expectation.”  -Rick Rubin
“The moment of creation makes us feel more alive.” -Rick Rubin
“One could argue that creativity 1s just variations on mistakes.”  -Rick Rubin
“The motivating factor  in the work is to like something. Then hopefully for someone else to like  1t too.”  -Rick Rubin
“Self-expression may not necessarily be egotistic. Wanting to be right is.” -Rick Rubin
“When receiving suggestions, you can also try the exact opposite and see what happens.”  -Rick Rubin
“Never allow the concept to limit you.” -Rick Rubin
“There may not be a line between a mistake and the free act of creation.”  -Rick Rubin
As long as we’re doing the work, it might as well be the kind that lasts forever.”  -Rick Rubin
“You make the wrong  turn on a drive, and you see something you wouldn’t have seen otherwise and that somehow informs the choices you make going forward.”  -Rick Rubin
Great art 1s timeless, and yetit’s a true expression of who the artist is in that moment.”  -Rick Rubin

Look for the feeling of being awakened to something. Hearing something and wondering, “What is that?”  -Rick Rubin
“Every time something out of the ordinary occurs, look for possible meaning.” -Rick Rubin
“It's helpful to remember everything is in flux. And if everything is in flux, there can be no mistakes.”  -Rick Rubin
“Ideas don't come from out of the blue, and they don't come merely from us. We're tuning into them, overhearing them, remembering them, recognizing them.”  -Rick Rubin
“Start with the idea there are no rules about the thing you are creating”  -Rick Rubin
“Anything you're creating by yourself is still rooted in everything you've learned and seen over your life.” -Rick Rubin
“Can we learn the knowingness of knowing?” -Rick Rubin
“Sharing only what you see as excellent allows you to be more confident.”  -Rick Rubin
“Rules are expectations. Failure 1s merely an unmet expectation.”  -Rick Rubin
“Normal is average, and average doesn't seem like anything to aspire to.” -Rick Rubin
“What is the expression of your natural being?” -Rick Rubin
“There is wisdom in each experience that comes from doing the work.” -Rick Rubin
“Never assume you know anything.” -Rick Rubin
“Don’t let the voices in your head limit your creative freedom.”  -Rick Rubin
“Go with the version you feel most connected to. Not the ‘right’ version.” -Rick Rubin
“Don’t let the voices in your head limit your creative freedom.”  -Rick Rubin
“You never know when you’re going to do your best work. Be willing to experiment.”  -Rick Rubin
“Sometimes the answer comes when you forget about the question.” -Rick Rubin
“The clues are everywhere.” -Rick Rubin
“Sometimes when starting a project, the less you know, the more original your creation may be.”  -Rick Rubin
“There are phases in the creative process, and no two phases work the same way. ” -Rick Rubin
“What matters is the work, not the method.” -Rick Rubin
“A constant in every stage of creativity is the need to remain open and unattached.”  -Rick Rubin
“Having a sound or vision in your head is a limitation, if you’re attached to it.” -Rick Rubin
“Just as cloud turns to rain, rain to ocean, ocean to cloud... There’s a circulation of energetic ideas.”  -Rick Rubin
“Listen to the world around you. Pay close attention.” -Rick Rubin
“Pay attention when you’re not paying attention.” -Rick Rubin
“Having a sound or vision in your head is a limitation, if you’re attached to it.” -Rick Rubin
“Every time something out of the ordinary happens, investigate it closely.”  -Rick Rubin
“Reality tells us what we can’t do. The artist has no use for reality.” -Rick Rubin
Great art is timeless, and yet it’s a true expression of who the artist is in that moment.”  -Rick Rubin
“Never allow the concept to limit you.” -Rick Rubin
“There may not be a line between a mistake and the free act of creation.”  -Rick Rubin
“When an idea strikes, take it as far as it can go quickly.  Don’t get stuck on a detail.” -Rick Rubin
If you’re not enjoying it and there’s not much sense of love in it, how can the  work be good?  -Rick Rubin
“There’s nothing wrong with riding a wave of enthusiasm to the end, but it’s better not to judge the work when you're in that state.” -Rick Rubin
“Retain a sense of play, of not being too precious.” -Rick Rubin
“Feel free to try a lot of ideas. Remove any expectations, any sense of what you should or shouldn’t do.”  -Rick Rubin
“When an idea strikes, take it as far as it can go. Quickly. Don’t get stuck on a detail.”  -Rick Rubin
“There’s a time to take the work seriously, but not in the moment of inspiration.” -Rick Rubin
“Iry not to let the voices in your head get in the way.” -Rick Rubin
“You never know when you’re going to do your best work. Be willing to experiment.”  -Rick Rubin
“When we think we’re protecting our territory, we’re actually limiting it.” -Rick Rubin
“Go with the version you feel most connected to. Not the ‘right’ version.” -Rick Rubin
“You never know when you’re going to do your best work. Be willing to experiment.”  -Rick Rubin
“Take advantage of creative rolls. No thinking. This 1s the mania moment.” -Rick Rubin
“Retain a sense of play, of not being too precious.” -Rick Rubin
“Don’t assume that the time you've put into a project has made it better.”  -Rick Rubin
“Context changes as an idea itself changes and as the day changes and as you change.” -Rick Rubin
“It's all about patience.” -Rick Rubin
“It’s easy to undermine what seemed awe-inspiring in the moment of inspiration.”  -Rick Rubin
“When you’re new to something, you bring an ignorance that can be highly innovative.”  -Rick Rubin
“If you make a sketch and decide this is all it can ever be, you'll never know if the painting would have been better.”  -Rick Rubin
“We often spend more time waiting for, and protecting, transcendental moments than “actively making" anything.”  -Rick Rubin
“We have no control.  It is out of our hands. Now go make it happen.” -Rick Rubin
“What matters is keeping the feeling—the true, special, resonant feeling that made you care about the idea in the first place.”  -Rick Rubin
“Creative work 1sn’t all mnovation all the time. Experience gives an archive to draw from.”  -Rick Rubin
“If you have a revision, try it and then let go of it and say, “Okay, now 1s the work better than it was?” -Rick Rubin
“Sometimes the idea is just a jumping off point for a grander work that’s nothing like the original idea.”  -Rick Rubin
“It’s easy to undermine what seemed awe-inspiring in the moment of inspiration.”  -Rick Rubin
“Never turn a limitation nto an excuse.” -Rick Rubin
“For some people  a first thing to learn  is the ability to process criticism skillfully.” -Rick Rubin
“If you are open and stay tuned to what’s happening, the answers will be revealed.” -Rick Rubin
“Everyone has different taste. There 1s no right or wrong taste.”  -Rick Rubin
“Aiming at greatness is different than aiming at being better than somebody else.”  -Rick Rubin
“It’s not only accidental. There’s intention in the idea, and in the work itself. Intention and experimentation.”  -Rick Rubin
“What makes an artist great 1s the ability to access the inner world we all have but that most others can’t access.”  -Rick Rubin
“Set the stage for something to happen. Something incredible. Something unexpected.” -Rick Rubin
“There’s no such thing as a bad creation. Sometimes the seemingly bad ones have to happen or a  good one to come.”  -Rick Rubin
“Do the work and the work will do the rest.” -Rick Rubin
“Working on several projects at once can help open a channel. Notice which ones take on a  life of their own.”  -Rick Rubin
‘“Anything we practice, we improve. Including releasing our inner world.”  -Rick Rubin
“Being a great artist means practicing being in touch with the information already inside you.”  -Rick Rubin
“The scale of the project doesn’t matter. It’s always good to practice your craft, You can never lose by doing so.”  -Rick Rubin
“Moving forward on new things can give you clarity. Clarity to step back and make the necessary decisions without getting In your own way.”  -Rick Rubin
“It’s worth trying many different methods with this in mind: there’s no way to know in advance whether any of them will work.” -Rick Rubin
“Always remain open  to turns and surprises along the way. Welcome the unexpected.”  -Rick Rubin
“Maybe the best idea  is the one you’re going to come up with this evening.” -Rick Rubin
“Keep working until you get something better than what you started with. Otherwise the starting point is it. The beginning is the end.”  -Rick Rubin
“As the idea develops, does it live up to or surpass the promise of the spark that originally got you excited?” -Rick Rubin
“Goals can be dangerous. When you reach them, you might mistakenly assume you accomplished something.”  -Rick Rubin
“Progress 1s made quickly through small steps.” -Rick Rubin
“It doesn’t matter if the work begins as an inspired idea or a homework assignment, as a passion or a throwaway.  Your greatest work may come from your least inspired moment.”  -Rick Rubin
“Allow yourself to see where things go, without forcing them.”  -Rick Rubin
“All music is Spiritual.” -Rick Rubin
“Sometimes the smallest ideas are the biggest ideas.” -Rick Rubin
“Some find it hard to accept something can be good when it comes easily. And some think that if it doesn’t come easily,  it can’t be good.”  -Rick Rubin
“We work based on the truth of who we are today;, not who we remember being yesterday.”  -Rick Rubin
“The amount of time and effort that goes into it doesn’t matter.”  -Rick Rubin
“What works for you one day may not work the next day, and that’s fine.”  -Rick Rubin
“The order or the amount of work that goes into a project isn’t what it’s about. Avoid getting the mechanics confused with the project itself.”  -Rick Rubin
“The more you practice your work, the better it will be. Practice opens channels of possibility in the brain.”  -Rick Rubin
“T'he person who makes something today isn’t the same person who returns to the work tomorrow.” -Rick Rubin
“It’s not helpful to be attached to the result being anything like the starting point.” -Rick Rubin
“Our opportunity is to practice. And what wants to happen, will happen.” -Rick Rubin
“See your work as if it’s your first time...  Just like the audience gets to experience it.”  -Rick Rubin
“If 1t’s your best in this moment, that’s the best it can be.  Tomorrow your best may be completely different.”  -Rick Rubin
“The work reveals itself as you go. It tells you what it wants to be.” -Rick Rubin
“The amount of time and effort that goes into it doesn’t matter.”  -Rick Rubin
“So much of the creative act 1s critical judgment and editing.”  -Rick Rubin
“When editing practice non-attachment.” -Rick Rubin
“If you keep it fresh and interesting for you, maybe it will strike the audience as fresh and interesting as well.”  -Rick Rubin
“Only after gathering all of the material can a deadline can be useful.”  -Rick Rubin
“It’s helpful to limit your exposure to a work in progress.”  -Rick Rubin
“T'here really aren’t any rules, just tools to help you make the best decisions.” -Rick Rubin
“The essence is an organizing principle.” -Rick Rubin
“What works for you one day may not work the next day, and that’s fine.”  -Rick Rubin
“Reduce your work to the absolute essentials you can’t live without.”  -Rick Rubin
“By listening to a work in progress too often, you can set a pattern in your brain, which makes it hard to change.”  -Rick Rubin
“The closer we can come to experiencing our work as the audience experiences it, the better position we're in to evaluate it.”  -Rick Rubin
“Learning to recognize when something is at its essential isn’t easy. It’s instinct. It’s an inner knowingness.” -Rick Rubin
“How do you explain elegance?” -Rick Rubin
“It’s possible to think you're moving forward, and you are. But you may not be moving forward in the  way you think you are.” -Rick Rubin
“How do you know when the work 1s done? There’s a sense of knowingness. You just know, even if you don’t know how  you know. ”’  -Rick Rubin
“It’s helpful if, after some time away, you can come back to your work with a more clear perspective.  Use time to test your work instead of just reacting to it in the moment.”  -Rick Rubin
“Just because it’s not clear if the work is done doesn’t mean it’s not moving in the right direction.”  ~Rick Rubin
“It’s difficult to have a clear perspective on your own work. It’s very hard to know yourself.”  -Rick Rubin
“For some people,  the work never feels quite right. Even though with all our efforts, imperfection is the norm.”  -Rick Rubin

“It’s not unusual for  an artist to recognize something wrong with a work and want to discard the whole thing. With art, it’s almost never all or nothing.  in life, this holds  true as well.”  -Rick Rubin
“Sometimes deciding a work 1s finished  1s more of a surrender than a victory.”  -Rick Rubin
“Getting everything right 1sn't always what’s best or most important.”  -Rick Rubin
“Learn to disconnect.” -Rick Rubin
“The unchosen is always present in the work.” -Rick Rubin
“Sometimes deciding a work 1s finished has more to do with the person deciding than with the work itself.” -Rick Rubin
“The editing process can be like this:  When the work has five mistakes, it’s not finished. But when it has eight mistakes, 1t 18.”  -Rick Rubin
“Details are important. Untl suddenly you go from making critical choices to less consequential ones.” -Rick Rubin
“With every choice, there’s loss.” -Rick Rubin
“Be open to a work’s strengths and weaknesses. As opposed to solely focusing on a weakness, allowing it to overwhelm the strengths.”  -Rick Rubin
“Get in the habit of just making things for fun. Not for anyone else.  No stakes.  No consequences.  Only for yourself.”  -Rick Rubin
“Once it becomes hard to tell the difference between one choice and another, it’s probably a less essential decision.”  -Rick Rubin
“One of the things that can slow down the creative process—or completing a work—is the unrealistic search for perfection.” -Rick Rubin
“Attention to detail always serves you until it doesn’t.” -Rick Rubin
“It’s impossible to predict how you’ll feel about a work tomorrow. All it really has to do 1s reflect this present moment in time.”  -Rick Rubin
“Is the work a true reflection of where you are in this moment... And how i1s this moment alike or different from others?”  -Rick Rubin
“Is it ime for the next project because the clock or calendar says it’s time, or because the work itself says it’s time?”  -Rick Rubin
“The more material you’ve built up,  the easier it 1s to assess the individual pieces.” -Rick Rubin
“Start working on the next thing.” -Rick Rubin
“When you see something beautiful, more often than not, you don’t know why it’s beautiful. You just see it, and you have the feeling. Not a decision but a reaction.”  -Rick Rubin
“Often, by gathering more ideas, the best way forward will arrive.”  -Rick Rubin
“Avoid allowing analysis to undermine inner knowingness.”  -Rick Rubin
“Sometimes thinking about it undermines the process.”  -Rick Rubin
“Always see 1f 1t can  be better. Always check back to make sure you didn’t ruin it.”  -Rick Rubin
“It may not be  necessary to recognize the architectural underpinnings of why things make us feel the way they do.”  -Rick Rubin
“It’s worth finding a way to really be free,  even from your own thoughts.”  -Rick Rubin
“When changing a small detail, it is possible to collapse the entire work... breath on it wrong and the whole thing blows away.”  -Rick Rubin
“Don’t make decisions only in your head.” -Rick Rubin
“When you try something physically, it resonates in a different way than it  did when you just imagined it.”  -Rick Rubin
“Start from the presumption we know nothing.”  -Rick Rubin
“We have a work principal in the studio: Demonstrate it, don't explain it.”  -Rick Rubin
“Ultimately the decisions we make—the editing choices—aren’t personal.” -Rick Rubin
“Sometimes the way you engage physically in the process can have an effect on the outcome.”  -Rick Rubin
“The challenge of being forced outside your normal patterns can lead to new ways of thinking and behaving that open  doors never noticed before.”  -Rick Rubin
“Do you analyze your understanding of life in the same way you analyze your work?” -Rick Rubin
“When you have options to choose from, pretty good seems to be  pretty good—not better than it really is.”  -Rick Rubin
“Iry every idea, every thought.” -Rick Rubin
“We’re 1n service to the work more than to the audience.”  -Rick Rubin
“T'he goal is to make something using the best of your ability and the truest version of who you are.”  -Rick Rubin
“Even in the midst of ruthless editing, try to treat what you’re creating with the respect and delicacy it deserves.”  Rick Rubin
“The things we make, we’re making for everyone, and we’re making them for forever.”  -Rick Rubin
“Commercial ambition can cloud creative choices.” -Rick Rubin
“Putting commercial concerns before personal taste is a losing battle.” -Rick Rubin
“The better choice artistically is usually going to be the better choice commercially.”  -Rick Rubin
“You’re successful as soon as you send your work out into the world.”  -Rick Rubin
“You don’t always have to take the audience by the hand and walk them through your work.” -Rick Rubin
“Sometimes we just supply the signposts.” -Rick Rubin
“Sometimes meaning follows the work. Sometimes we only understand the meaning later.”  -Rick Rubin
“Always aim for your highest meaning;  And never underestimate the audience’s ability to get your highest meaning.” -Rick Rubin
“Meaning cannot always be put into words.  Often it’s a heightened sense of aliveness you feel in the presence  of the work.”  -Rick Rubin
“Meaning is the deeper resonance.  Even when you may not know the meaning.” -Rick Rubin
“What’s unexpressed has power.” -Rick Rubin
“Holding your work hostage to your meaning 1s a limitation.”  -Rick Rubin
“Leave room for interpretation.” -Rick Rubin
“All that matters is that you get to express yourself, and the audience gets something that speaks to them, even if these two things are not the same.” -Rick Rubin
“The best way to serve the audience is to ignore them.” -Rick Rubin
“If you’re reacting to  a response to your work, you’re not in the work any more.”  -Rick Rubin
“Being aware of the audience as you’re making your work changes it.” ~Rick Rubin
“You’re making your work as a gift.” -Rick Rubin
“What you have to offer 1s what’s inside of you.” -Rick Rubin
“Make the best thing for you, and then share it.” -Rick Rubin
“Its always ultimatly  for you,  for your own satisfaction. Thats the best choice you have aesthetically.”  -Rick Rubin
“Nobody knows what anyone else 1s going to like.” -Rick Rubin

“If you’re really good at your craft, you can create something with a purely commercial intention,  and it may succeed in  that way. But it’s not likely to have the long-term importance and resonance that a skillful work would.” -Rick Rubin
“Be true to your voice and to your art.” -Rick Rubin
“I don’t know anything, but I trust my taste.” -Rick Rubin
“The time for commercial considerations is after the work 1s completed.”  -Rick Rubin
“If the work connects artistically,  1t’s a success.”  -Rick Rubin
“You can’t control people’s interpretation. And why would you want to?”  -Rick Rubin
“Not everything is for everybody.” -Rick Rubin
“If people see a work for what it 1s, that’s great.  If they see it as something different, that’s fine too.” -Rick Rubin
“Getting everything right 1sn't always what’s best or most important.”  -Rick Rubin
“Something less perfect may seem more human, more real. Ultimately, more desirable.”  Rick Rubin
“Paying attention is part of self-expression.” -Rick Rubin
“We can undervalue a work made quickly.  We can overvalue a work labored on.  Time invested is irrelevant.” -Rick Rubin
“If you don’t let it go, the process of finishing a work can be endless.” -Rick Rubin
“Maybe 1in fifty years,  the work you like best ends up being people’s favorite of yours as well.” -Rick Rubin
“There’s no way of knowing.” -Rick Rubin
“Everyone has the ability to see the end.” -Rick Rubin
“It's unlikely anyone else  in the world will care about the details that worry you. Remembering this helps keep perspective.”  -Rick Rubin
‘“Avoid getting lost in the dark hole of over-absorption.” -Rick Rubin
“Finishing is when there’s no more work to do.” -Rick Rubin
‘Art doesn’t get made on the clock, but it does get finished on the clock.” -Rick Rubin
“Create space to allow the thing you want to come in to come in.”  -Rick Rubin
“The reason to finish is to start something new.” -Rick Rubin
“Everyone has the ability to see the end.” -Rick Rubin
“Some can see the end the day they begin. Others can’t see it untl it’s upon them. One 1s not better than the other.”  -Rick Rubin
“Finish this project in service to the next one. And also 1n service to the project you’re working on.” -Rick Rubin
“Complete the project so you can take the risk of sharing it.  The risk is the price  of creation.”  -Rick Rubin
“Up untl the time you  let go of the work,  you can still improve it.  So letting go is just a moment in time,  an accurate representation of where you were in that Instant.”  -Rick Rubin
“When collaborating,  it’s best to either not have a way of doing things or to offer your way as a solution while being open to other possible solutions.”  -Rick Rubin
“In a collaboration, if the best idea gets picked, you win, regardless of whose idea it 1s.”  -Rick Rubin
“Creativity can just be in relationship with yourself. No one else need be in the equation.”  -Rick Rubin
“Art 1s nourishment.” -Rick Rubin
“We are born artists. And then society does its best to beat it out of us.” -Rick Rubin
“Talent is the ability to let 1deas manifest themselves through you.”  -Rick Rubin
“Thinking doesn’t always solve the problem. Sometimes creating space allows inspiration to do the work.”  -Rick Rubin
“Our path is to collaborate with what’s happening; Not to fight it.”  -Rick Rubin
“Have the confidence to jump in with both feet.” -Rick Rubin
“Sometimes the way you engage physically in the process can have an effect on the outcome.”  -Rick Rubin
“When you try something physically, it resonates in a different way than it  did when you just imagined it.”  -Rick Rubin
“Don’t make decisions only in your head.” -Rick Rubin
“Do you want to be right. Or do you want what’s best for the work.”  -Rick Rubin
“True collaboration 1sn't rooted 1n versus and settling.”  -Rick Rubin
“Cooperation isn’t giving in. It's clearly sharing your feelings to reach a  greater good.”  -Rick Rubin
“When giving in to someone else, everybody loses. Cooperate instead of capitulate.”  -Rick Rubin
“Sometimes what looks like collaboration is merely sublimating egos.  Not actually working together.”  -Rick Rubin
“Many different models of collaboration exist: monarchical, dictatorial, unanimous, democratic. Nearly all of them can work.”  -Rick Rubin
“In a group of four, the work you like unanimously will likely be better than the work only three of you like.” -Rick Rubin
“Sometimes it’s the friction that allows the fire to come—as long as 1t’s a skillful friction.” -Rick Rubin
“When it comes to making creative decisions, knowing less—having little information—is often better than knowing more. It’s a way of staying unattached.”  -Rick Rubin
“Success has a way of undermining artists.” -Rick Rubin
“Do the work and the work will do the rest.” -Rick Rubin
“Set the stage for something to happen. Something incredible. Something unexpected.” -Rick Rubin
‘“Always remain open to turns and surprises along the way. Welcome the unexpected.”  -Rick Rubin
“T'he person who makes something today isn’t the same person who returns to the work tomorrow.” -Rick Rubin
“Reduce your work to the absolute essentials you can’t live without.”  -Rick Rubin
“The unchosen is always present in the work.” -Rick Rubin
“How do you explain elegance?” -Rick Rubin
“To my mind,  much of the work of being an artist is about letting go of ego.” -Rick Rubin
“Even though we work diligently to make it happen, no one’s really prepared for what success 1s actually like.”  -Rick Rubin
“Success tends to bolster ego.  This can effectively take away the edge you had before an audience was paying attention.”  -Rick Rubin
“Aspiring artists have a desire to be seen. Established artists face the pressure of knowing they’ll be seen.”  -Rick Rubin
“Are you leading? Or following?  And does it matter?” -Rick Rubin
“lo react against what people expect is the same as doing what they want.” -Rick Rubin
“If you let success dictate what you do next, you're not being true to yourself. You're putting yourself in a small box.”  -Rick Rubin
“No one teaches us how to deal with success.” -Rick Rubin
“Avoid thinking of your  old work as being better or worse than your new work. It’s always different—a new reflection of a new you,  the result of more time.” -Rick Rubin
“If you’re committed to doing your best work at all times, your best work 1is always today.”  -Rick Rubin
“Some great artists undermine themselves  by setting an unrealistic goal based on the perceived successes and trappings they see around them.” -Rick Rubin
“Working as an artist means collaborating with the culture.  It may include being inspired by a current wave or rejecting it.”  -Rick Rubin
“There’s a time for certain ideas to arrive, and they find a way to express themselves through us.”  -Rick Rubin
“Train yourself to see the awe beyond the obvious.” -Rick Rubin
“T'he more narrow your view of the world, the less you see. Widen your vision to see the possibilities.” -Rick Rubin
“The challenge is to grow along with what you’re creating.”  -Rick Rubin
“The goal is always to get closer to your true self.” -Rick Rubin
“If you practice the habit of speaking and writing only the truth, maybe this skillful habit will work its way into your heart and you’ll become more at ease.”  -Rick Rubin
“Making a beautiful thing is a noble pursuit.” -Rick Rubin
“It’s worth creating a safe environment—a working environment—where you’re free enough to express what you're afraid to.  If only for yourself.”  -Rick Rubin
“You get to choose what you share.” -Rick Rubin
“If you consider the stories told at an AA meeting,  the healing is for both the person hearing the story and the person telling it. The same is true in art.” -Rick Rubin
“Sometimes the therapeutic value of making the work  is the outcome. And that’s enough.”  -Rick Rubin
“It doesn’t have to be done professionally.” -Rick Rubin
“We are dealing in a magic realm.  And nobody knows why or how it works.”  -Rick Rubin
“You can choose not  to write, not to make art. You are not obligated  to do so.”  -Rick Rubin
“Any creative path is difficult.” -Rick Rubin
